channel.title: ahoylemon üçã xyz
channel.description: I make a lot of stuff, including this website to show the stuff I make.

item.title: Comparatively Famous
item.description:
This is a game about guessing the relative value of different celebrities on Cameo.

I built this one in about a week and a half.

item.title: Invalid
item.description: Invalid! was the first game for my kinda.fun website. The basic premise is that every employee is trying to create a password, while the SysAdmin is busy making their lives miserable.

item.title: damn.dog
item.description:
The game that shows you an actual WikiHow illustration, and asks you which actual Wikihow article it came from.

Called ‚ÄúThe Best Game On The Internet‚Äù by Gizmodo, this project has been the subject of literally hundreds of YouTube videos.

item.title: Sisyphus Clicker
item.description:
In this clicker game, you tap on Sisyphus to roll the rock uphill. Once the rock gets near the top, it will roll back downhill.

Also, there are acheivements.

item.title: Idiots win.
item.description:
The game that challenges you to figure out what people are searching for on Google.

Idiots Win takes a search query, sends it to Google for autocomplete suggestions, then randomizes them and asks you to guess the top.

item.title: The Wrongest Words
item.description: The Wrongest Words launched as the second game on kinda.fun. It's a multiplayer game where each player must defend the stupid statements in front of them.

item.title: PRETEND üåê WORLD
item.description:
You are at a party of celebrity impersonators. It's up to you to guess which ones.

This was first launched for KCDC X

item.title: Not Poutine, FYI
item.description:
Poutine is a dish made with french fries, fresh cheese curds and brown gravy.

This site catalogs meals that describe themselves as poutine and yet are not poutine.

item.title: BG2üòéCOOL
item.description:
We've spent enough of our lives looking at flat, minimalist websites that all look art directed by the same person. Let's turn this ship around.

BG2COOL provides you with patterns and options. Make your choices, and the site will hand you some CSS.

item.title: Great Sex Tips!
item.description: Birthed from a conversation about the editing process of Cosmo's sex tips, this is a site that generates hetero sex advice for women to please their men. How exhilerating!

item.title: Heelies Info
item.description: My friend likes the website Wookieepedia a lot and then he had a birthday. So I made a Wookieepedia page just for him.

item.title: 2UN üîµ LTD
item.description: This is a very important website that asks if if you're ready for this. And if you are ready for this, appropriate measures will be taken.

item.title: PARTY PARTY PARTY PARTY PARTY
item.description: This is a button to help you party.

image.title: PARTY PARTY PARTY PARTY PARTY logo

item.title: Bad Accent Club
item.description: The Android game that puts your friends' accents to the test (and they will usually fail the test).

item.title: jerking online
item.description:
Working from a shockingly long list of fake porn titles my friends and I have come up with, this site promises new titles every day.

Cause it makes me giggle.

item.title: dumb men
item.description: This is a online web experience when men rain down from the sky! What kind of men? Well, it's up to you to find out.

item.title: Verifiable Win
item.description: Launched as part of a talk at NDC Minnesota 2018, this is a site to demonstrate you're right about whatever you think.

item.title: @rickross_daily
item.description: This twitterbot (which was either the idea of JW Friedman or myself, we can't remember) will inform you what Rick Ross is doing every day, every day.

item.title: pl_swiftwater
item.description:
My friend Schwa and I collaborated on a Team Fortress 2 map called Swiftwater. He did the geometry, I did the art assets and built the story of a bottled water company at war with a chemical mining concern.

In 2016, Valve bought the map and made it official.

item.title: Frank West Pronounces Emoticons
item.description:
Frank West sometimes pronounces emoticons. And now, via this soundboard, he does it on your command.

Even in comparison to the other sites on this page, this one is really stupid.

item.title: Hamilton -> DOOM
item.description: This is a Chrome extension that replaces all instances of ‚ÄúHamilton‚Äù with ‚Äúthe video game DOOM‚Äù. For obvious reasons.

item.title: Recent Firings In San Francisco
item.description:
I wanted to make a site that would give the user up-the-second updates of who was just fired in the San Francisco Tech Industry.

In reality, it just works an alogorithm to generate random strings.

image.title: Recent Firings In San Francisco logo

item.title: The F Plus
item.description:
I do a podcast, and also work a fair amount on the website for that podcast, which is a complicated piece of web development.

That said, I'm pretty happy with how this whole thing works.

item.title: ballp.it
item.description: ballp.it is the forum set up to support the community that surrounds The F Plus. It uses PHP software called SMF, but has been modified heavily.

item.title: Me Making Websites IRL
item.description:
Using an open source software called ‚ÄúGource‚Äù, I made this 3.5 minute YouTube video documenting the process of building most of the websites on this list, set to a Paper Chase song.

Not incredibly informative, but fun to look at.

item.title: üçã/talks
item.description: I do a certain amount of public speaking. Here is a pge with places I've been, and places where I'm going.

item.title: üçã/clients
item.description: Of course, I make websites for money. This page lists some websites I've done for clients, and the tech I've used on those sites.

item.title: üçã/uses
item.description: I just recently came across Wes Bos' Awesome Uses repository. I thought it was interesting to look at the toolkit that other people used, and thought I'd provide my own. But sometimes the tools a person uses are more about something being the "good enough" option, so I thought I'd get a little more specific: Those things marked with a are things which I think are great and totally recommend. Those things marked with a are things which I've compromised into using for one way or another. It's the best I've found, but you could talk me into something else.

item.title: üçã/üçé
item.description: Hi, I wanted you personally to see a list of some actual apple names, and some that aren't.

item.title: üçã/feed
item.description: An RSS feed? Why!?

item.title: üçã/sitemap
item.description: Let's build a sitemap, we can make it our best friend.
